title: Deep Dive: How Intent Swaps Work
summary: A technical look at the lifecycle of an intent, from signing to Dutch Auction settlement.
content:
The Intent Lifecycle

When you place a Market Order on Intent Protocol, you aren't just sending a transaction. You are initiating a Dutch Auction.

1. Quote & Signature

The frontend calculates a price range starting slightly above market price (to incentivize relayers) and decaying over time. You sign this entire curve as a single EIP-712 message.

2. The Dutch Auction

Relayers monitor your order off-chain. As time passes, the price of your order becomes more attractive to them.

Example: You want to sell 100 MOVE.
- T+0s: Relayer must pay 105 USDC (Too expensive)
- T+5s: Relayer must pay 101 USDC (Fair)
- T+10s: Relayer must pay 99 USDC (Profitable!)

3. Settlement

The first Relayer to find the order profitable submits the transaction on-chain. The Move contract verifies your signature and atomically swaps the assets. You receive your USDC, and the Relayer receives your MOVE.
